The acronym MARIE stands for "Machine Architecture that is Really Intuitive and Easy."
The Accumulator in MARIE's CPU is used to store instructions temporarily before they are processed.

The Memory Buffer Register (MBR) in MARIE is responsible for fetching data from or storing data to memory.

In MARIE, the Control Unit is responsible for directing the operation of the processor.
The ALU in MARIE is responsible for storing data before it’s written to memory.
MARIE’s main memory consists of 8K words.
In the fetch-decode-execute cycle, the instruction is decoded immediately after it is fetched.
In MARIE, the Memory Address Register (MAR) holds the address of the data to be fetched or stored.
Executing the Halt instruction in MARIE causes the CPU to stop fetching and executing instructions.
The "store" instruction in MARIE writes data from the Accumulator (AC) to memory.
The Datapath in MARIE’s CPU is responsible for fetching the next instruction to be executed.
The ALU in MARIE can perform both addition and multiplication operations.
